full_text:
Case 20-3061, Document 60, 09/24/2020, 2938278, Page38 of 58

Martindell, 594 F.2d at 296. But unless Judge Nathan's order is reversed in the criminal case, Ms. Maxwell cannot share this information with Judge Preska in the civil case.8

Conclusion

In the end, the government's argument amounts to little more than this:

Judge Preska should remain in the dark. But there's no principled justification for that position, and this Court should reject it.

This Court should reverse the district court's order denying Ms. Maxwell's motion to modify the protective order.

September 24, 2020.

8 Nor, unless the cases are consolidated, will the panel of this Court considering the civil appeal know [REDACTED]

33

DOJ-OGR-00019437

Judge Preska should remain in the dark. But there's no principled justification for that position, and this Court should reject it.
This Court should reverse the district court's order denying Ms. Maxwell's motion to modify the protective order.
